title: CTRL0000071090 - Transcribed Interview of John Isakson, (April 25, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Zoom, commencing at 10:03 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is the transcribed interview of John Isakson
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd like to ask the witness to please state your full name and spell
your last name for the record.
My name is John Andrew Isakson.
Counsel, would you like to state your name also for an appearance?
Stefan Passantino of the law firm Michael Best &
So this will be a staff-led interview.
Members of the select committee may, of
If they do so, you should be able to see them in a participant list
on the Zoom screen here, and we will also do our best to announce their presence when
As I said, this is going to be staff led.
investigative counsel with the select committee.
my c o l l e a g u e , ~ h o is also an investigative counsel with the select
I'm joined here in the room today by
And we have a couple of other members of our staff who are participating
You can see them on a participant list.
So a few ground rules just to cover before we get started today, Mr. Isakson.
This is being conducted in executive session, this transcribed interview of the
So that means neither committee members nor staff will discuss the
substance of the testimony you provide today unless the committee has approved
You and your attorney will have an opportunity to review the transcript.
And just some general reminders of interview/deposition best practices, especially
when we're doing it under these remote virtual circumstances.
The official reporters are on the line here today.
They're going to be taking a
transcript of our questions and your answers.
and video from this Zoom call, the official reporters' transcript is the official record of our
Even though we are recording the audio
So to make that record as clean as possible, we'll ask for you to wait until we finish
our questions before you start your answers.
And we will also try to do our best to wait
to make sure that your answers are complete before we ask our next question, just so
that we're not talking over each other.
If at any time you have any questions about or need to seek clarity about any of
We want you to tell us today to the best of your
So if there's something that you don't recall, then "I don't recall" is the
But, of course, if you do, you should tell us what it is that you recall.
Even though this is not under oath, I will remind you that this is an official
proceeding of Congress and deliberately providing false information to Congress could be
Logistically here today, I don't think that we'll be here for
But if at any point you'd like to take a break, whether for a comfort
break or to confer with your attorney, we're absolutely happy to do so.
We can go on mute and off video here so that you would have a chance to confer
Any questions about those ground rules or anything you'd
like to address, Mr. Passantino, before we get going?
I think we're ready to proceed.
So, Mr. Isakson, let's go over just a little bit of background.
Where is it that you -- where do you reside?
I live in Cobb County, Georgia, northwest Atlanta, just inside the perimeter.
And how long have you lived in Georgia?
All of my life, with the exception of college at Tulane University and a short
And why don't you give us a brief summary of your educational and
I have an undergraduate degree in economics from Tulane University and I
have a graduate degree in economics from the University of Georgia.
And in what industry have you made your professional career?
developer here in Atlanta, worked there for about 5 years before I started my own firm.
When I got out of graduate school, I went to work for Wachovia Bank in real
I spent a couple of years there.
I went to work for a private real estate
Approximately 2005, I merged my firm in with a larger organization here in Atlanta
and proceeded to run a private equity fund.
And then eventually we took the company
public -- or part of the company public -- in 2011, Preferred Apartment Communities, of
which I am now the chief financial officer.
And what has been your connection with the Georgia Republican Party?
I've served in a variety of voluntary and consultative roles for State, local,
Federal candidates over the last 35 years.
Have you held elected office in Georgia?
And have you had experience with election law before?
So you're here today because of your selection as a Republican elector in the 2020
And have you served as an elector in a Presidential election before 2020?
Why don't you tell us, to the best of your recollection, the process
by which you became one of the electors that was nominated to serve as a Presidential
I was invited to qualify as an elector.
capitol and fill out some forms or sign something.
the process, as I recall it.
I had to go down to the State
And then I was on the ballot.
And it's my understanding that Mr. Shafer is and was at that time the chair
And you said you were invited.
of the Republican Party in Georgia.
How long have you known Mr. Shafer?
And at the time that Mr. Shafer invited you to serve or to apply for your candidacy
for the -- to be a Presidential elector, what was generally your understanding of what that
would entail, what would be expected of you in the role?
We would -- all the electors would be on the ballot.
won, we went to Washington to cast our votes in the electoral college.
And is that sense of the role, did you receive that from your
I don't recall any other details from our conversation about
responsibilities or what was going to happen.
It was not a long conversation.
Did you speak to anyone else at the time, before the election, at the
time that you were nominated as a Presidential elector, did you speak to anyone else
about the role or what would be expected of you?
And what about the other electors for Georgia, the other Republican
electors, that is, were you familiar with any of the other folks on that list?
Some of them, yes, but not all of them.
candidacy to be a Republican elector, just generally tell us what did that entail.
I went down to the State capitol.
And I went in and there was a -- I think I had to show my driver's license and there
And then I turned the form in, and that was it.
Do you remember approximately when it was that you went down
to the capital and turned in your form?
And when you went to the capital to submit your paperwork, your
Well, I mean, it would have had to have been before the primary.
So from that time in the spring of 2020 when you turned in your form for your
candidacy as a Presidential elector until the Presidential election on November 3rd, did
you have any other communications about your role as a Presidential elector?
And you weren't asked to do anything in the interim time period.
So at any point during this time, did you become aware of a concept
about convening electors in the event that the President had not -- that then President
Donald Trump had not won the State of Georgia?
We're going to talk later about the meeting that happened in
Trump-Pence ticket even though the State had been certified, the election had been
certified in Georgia for the Biden-Harris ticket, when was it that you first heard of this
The idea that the Trump-Pence electors would meet, notwithstanding the
So which concept are you referring to?
fact that the outcome of the election had been certified for the Biden-Harris ticket.
But just generally this idea of convening an alternate slate of electors for the
I'm a little confused by that question, because I don't -- I know about it after
So I think he's confused about the sequencing of
the timing I think that you're asking about.
the -- it came in the press or -- maybe if you could apply some timeframe and walk him
Are you asking about sort of before, before
Let me ask you specifically about like sort of each kind of relevant time
period, and then we'll get to the point where you did learn about it.
So I think I already asked you about before the election, so the time period in
between your candidacy and the election, and you told us that you had not heard
What about from the election until, say, early December?
Did you hear anything about this concept then?
And then what about in the days leading up to the electoral college
You told me this beforehand and I only lasted 15 minutes.
I'm breaking it down and repeating myself,
But so let me ask again.
So the time period in the days, let's say, the weekend
before and the days leading up to December 14th, did you hear about this alternate
When I was called by a Washington Post reporter earlier this year.
After December 14th did you come to learn about it?
Do you remember approximately when you received that call?
And you said earlier this year.
So let me ask you, before we go to that sort of fast-forward, let me
ask you some questions about the December time period.
said, some of this may already be covered by what you told us just now.
But in the time period after the election, after November 3rd, through December
14th or shortly after, so the sort of post-election time period, did you have any
communications with members or staff of the Trump reelection campaign?
I'm going to ask you a few names of individuals that were working
for or affiliated with the campaign.
recollection about any communications in this time period, but it would be also helpful to
hear if you generally know these individuals and had communications about the election
I'm asking you specifically to see if it jogs your
There's an individual named Robert Sinners.
What about an individual named Mike Roman?
So no communications with any of those individuals about anything
And what about other lawyers acting on behalf of the campaign?
What about some other staff members for the campaign?
have seen them in the news around this time period.
Giuliani, and associated with him were several individuals, including Jenna Ellis, Christina
They were led by Mayor Rudy
Did you have any interaction with any of those lawyers?
Earlier you said that you had some familiarity with other members
of the nominated or proposed slate of Trump-Pence electors in Georgia in 2020.
than David Shafer, who you've described already, who were the folks on that list that
Without having the list in front of me, there may be other
The two that I remember are Daryl Moody and Hennessy, Steve Hennessy.
I just -- those are the only two I -- I just don't know the
Actually, this might be the first opportunity for me to see if I can
So let me see if I can pull up the list for you.
You know, 2 years into the pandemic still figuring out Zoom.
years in, where are we, again?
So here this is a document that we marked
as exhibit 3, and here's the list.
Do you see that, Mr. Isakson?
Any other names of Trump-Pence electors on this list that you're
And I apologize, I had the wrong Hennessy.
And, I mean, I've met Burt Jones, but I don't -- I don't
But I misspoke when I said Steve Hennessy.
And just I pulled up a list that doesn't include your name.
slate that was submitted, and there's two more names that go onto the next page there.
So this includes the replaced four electors that hadn't been on the original slate but that
were present at the meeting on December 14th.
So for those individuals that you identified already that you knew, including
Mr. Hennessy, Mr. Hanna, Mr. Moody, did you have any conversations with them in the
post-election time period about the meeting of the Trump-Pence electors?
Neither before nor after the meeting itself?
So, Mr. Isakson, were you aware that members of the Trump
campaign staff were trying to reach you regarding this meeting that was to take place on
I received a phone call asking me to attend a meeting at the capitol.
was a gathering of the electors at the capitol on a Monday.
It wasn't someone I knew or recognized.
You said it was a phone call.
I think it was a Monday.
Did you speak to the person on the
other line or did they leave you a message?
And let me see if I can take this down.
Do you remember how far before the Monday meeting you received this phone
So it was Saturday or Sunday.
And do you remember what that person -- how they got your name
And it was actually -- it was over the weekend.
Was the individual who called you a man or a woman?
And did that person -- I know you said you couldn't recall the
identity, but did they identify themselves by their role, their reason for calling?
Let me show you one more document just to see if this helps.
Can you see this document, exhibit 6, Mr. Isakson?
This is not an email that you are on, but it mentions you.
It's an email dated Saturday, December 12th, 2020.
mentioned a moment ago named Robert Sinners.
It's from an individual that I
There are several individuals here on the "to" and the cc line, including David
Shafer; Stewart Bragg; a person with the last name Barrett, bbarrett for the email
address; Joshua Findlay with a donaldtrump.com email; and Mike Roman, who I also
Other than Mr. Shafer, are you familiar with any of the people on this email?
And I assume you would remember if it had been Mr. Shafer who
Any reason why you would be able to -- seeing these names, does it
ring any bells about who it was that reached out to you?
Yes, that I would have -- that part I would have remembered.
In this email, in the bullet points below, it's written by
Robert Sinners, and it is introduced "Today's progress was as follows."
Electors Update," and in the third bullet point it identifies your
name after Mark Hennessy, John Isakson, and then says, "have not responded via email,
Do you remember receiving other sort of outreach by email, text, or voicemail
from Mr. Sinners or anyone else associated with the campaign?
Somebody may have called me and left -- somebody else may have called
It may have been the same person that called me back that I picked up for.
didn't get an email or a text.
Let's go off the record for a few minutes.
It looks like you might be frozen.
It looks like we've lost the witness'
We're back on the record for the transcribed interview of John
Have you by any chance checked your phone to see if you still have
The earlier call, other than the one that you picked up on, did they
anything reflecting those calls on your cell phone?
So, Mr. Isakson, before our little tech hiccup there, you had told us that you
had received a couple of phone calls related to the December 14th meeting.
Have you ever -- have you had a chance to review your phone to see if you have
any records still on it relating to those calls?
I did review my phone and there were no voicemails.
What about any records of the incoming calls around that time
My phone doesn't save calls that far back.
So, just to recap, I believe what you've testified for us was that you received a
phone call, at least one call that you did not answer and then one call that you did.
may have been from the same individual, it may have been from another individual.
So the call that you did take and that you spoke to the individual on
the other end, you said that it was during the weekend before December 14th, possibly
So tell us what else you remember about what that individual told you about what
I only remember that it was over the weekend.
It was a very brief call.
He said there was a gathering at the capitol for the
I don't remember the exact words that he used.
And I indicated that I couldn't attend because of work.
Did the individual tell you what the gathering was for?
It came across to me like a
Again, I can't remember the exact words that he used.
What gave you the sense that it was a political rally?
In describing what was to occur on December 14th, did he refer to the casting of
Did he tell you -- let me rephrase that.
Did you have the sense that he was calling you because of your role as a
Again, he said that there was going to be this gathering and all the electors
Did he tell you anything about if you didn't attend what that would
Did he mention any comments about the need to find a replacement
for you if you didn't attend?
Did anyone ever provide you with any paperwork or tell you that
there was going to be paperwork that you would need to sign on the 14th?
Did the individual who called you over the weekend, did they give
you any sense for what the purpose, what the sort of reason was for why the electors
And did the person ask you either to keep it confidential, not to comment
publicly, or, in the alternative, to tell anyone else about it?
So I think you said that you told the individual that you couldn't
Did you consider attending and decide not to, or how much consideration
And what was your understanding of the status of the Presidential
I mean, I don't remember exactly where we were in that process.
don't remember what I was thinking.
election in Georgia at that time?
I mean, I have a full-time job and that was a conflict, so I didn't
spend a lot chime thinking about it.
If it's helpful just to -- I know it's been more than a year and a
half -- but going back to the timeline.
So the election itself was on November 3rd, but it took a fair amount of time in
several States, and in Georgia being one of them, to actually get all of the votes counted
Does that comport with your memory?
If it's helpful just to put some stakes in the ground as far as
It was November 19th, so more than -- a little more than 2 weeks after the
election when the Associated Press called the State of Georgia for Biden.
I mean, I recall the State was called for Biden, but I
don't recall the AP doing it or when that was.
But, generally speaking, at some point after the ballots had
been counted the media made a call that the Presidential election in Georgia had been
And then I can represent to you that on November 20th, 2020,
Governor Kemp made a public statement affirming the election results that the
Biden-Harris ticket had won the State of Georgia.
I can also represent to you that on December 7th the Governor of
Georgia, Governor Kemp, signed the official certificate of ascertainment for the outcome
What about just generally during this time period, do you remember
any of the actions or statements by the Governor of Georgia regarding the outcome of
I mean, I was paying attention at the time and I was aware of what the
Governor did, generally speaking, but I don't recall the specific dates or the specific
At the time that you received this call on the weekend of December 12th and
13th, though, was it your understanding or opinion that the outcome of the race was
determined, or did you believe that it was still in doubt?
I think what she's asking is whether you had an opinion about
the legal status of the race at that time period.
And don't let me characterize your question for you.
But I think that was the
question, but if you wanted to rephrase.
time whether he thought it was a -- the legal matter was still unresolved or --
Are you asking for his opinion about at the
I think really what I'm trying to get at, Mr. Isakson, is when you get this
phone call saying that there's going to be a meeting of the Trump-Pence electors on
December 14th, what was your state of mind at that time about whether -- which ticket
had won, whether the outcome of the race was certain at that point.
I mean, I was aware that the -- I was generally aware of the things you
mentioned, that the Governor had done what he had done.
But specifically what was happening, I really just don't
So when you get this phone call on December 12th, did it surprise
you to think that you still had a role to play as a Trump-Pence elector?
Again, I mean, it came across to me like a political rally and that I had just
been called because I was an elector.
I got the sense they were asking me to attend a rally.
And other than having had this phone call, sort of setting
So is it fair to say that you were not expecting to be casting electoral votes for
I didn't have any sense that they were asking me
that aside, but it sounds like you had work commitments lined up on the 14th.
I'll ask my colleague,_ if you have
anything to follow up on this.
Mr. Isakson, I just had -- I was hoping you could maybe unpack a
bit what you meant by political rally and what gave you the impression that this was a
crowd there, we want to pack the capitol?
For instance, did they say that there was going to be -- we want a large
What gave you that impression, to the
Again, it was a brief phone call over a year and a half ago.
just the impression that I had when I hung up is they were having a rally, they wanted the
But I don't have any other specific color or context that I can provide.
And we might have already touched this but just to confirm, in
that phone call do you remember the other person mentioning the state of the litigation
and that this meeting would have any sort of effect or could play a role in the litigation,
anything to do with the litigation going on in Georgia at the time?
On this call, Mr. Isakson, did the individual you were speaking with
mention that there was a similar kind of occurrence happening in other contested States
And on this phone call, were you invited to participate in any other
conference calls with the other Trump-Pence electors, either in Georgia or other States?
At any point later did anyone tell you the relationship between the
meeting of Trump-Pence electors in Georgia and this example of Hawaii following 1960?
Did the individual mention the example of what happened in Hawaii
So after that call on the weekend, did you reach out to Mr. Shafer or
anyone else to ask questions about this?
Did you discuss it with Mr. Shafer at any point?
After the article in The Washington Post came out.
So this year, 2022, you've spoken to Mr. Shafer about it?
But at any point after you had that phone call the weekend of
December 12th, 2020, through the inauguration of President Biden, did you have any
conversations with Mr. Shafer about this?
So I have here the quote that I think you're referring to that you
gave to the Washington Post reporter who reached out to you this year.
that you told them that you had bowed out because you did not want to attend what you
had perceived as a political rally.
And I think that's consistent with what you've told us
They also quoted you as saying, "It seemed like political
gamesmanship," and saying, "That's not something I would have participated in."
Is that a fair quote from you?
It's the context of the question.
So what were you referring to?
I know the quote has you saying it
in the past tense, it "seemed" like it was political gamesmanship.
formed this opinion that it seemed like political gamesmanship?
The reporter asked me if -- I said that -- I said what I said to you, which is I
thought it was a political rally and I have a full-time job and so I didn't go.
And she asked me, if you had known everything you know now, would you have
And I said what I said in the quote and I stand by it.
time and she asked me a hypothetical question.
So let me ask you that question too.
But I didn't know at the
Well, actually, let me first say, at the time
when you did not participate in the meeting on December 14th, did you have any
concerns about what was to happen on the 14th?
So the reason why you participated was not related to your
concerns about it being political gamesmanship and not something that you would have
Again, just to be clear, I thought it was a political rally.
But your characterization of it that was in The Washington Post as
far as political gamesmanship and not something that you would have participated in, is
that something that you thought at the time in 2020?
When I was asked the hypothetical question by the Washington Post
And when did you come to form that understanding of it?
And had you at that point when you got a phone call from the
reporter in 2022, had you learned about what occurred on the 14th in your absence in
The newspaper reporter was the -- her phone call was the first I learned of it.
So what did you understand at that point about what had
I mean, I -- to be honest with you, I hadn't -- I hadn't given it a thought since.
I mean, I thought they had -- I mean, we have lots of political rallies and I thought that
was just another one and just happened to be one of the ones I wasn't at.
So did you come to learn that the electors had signed certificates

The reporter informed me of that.
And what was generally your assessment of -- what was your
What was my assessment of that occurrence?
I mean, I had obviously heard about -- and I don't remember when I heard
Did it surprise you to learn that?
what and if it was -- I assume it was before the Washington Post lady called me.
remember exactly when I learned about that versus the timeline of this phone call.
I mean, I had heard about this idea of these alternate electors.
But I was surprised that they were calling me about it, because, obviously I didn't
So when they told me they had submitted an alternate slate, it
In The Washington Post, the quote from you continues to
say that, "We have a process for certifying the election.
something that was going against all of that."
The challenges failed so I wouldn't have participated in
Is that an accurate quote from you?
Again, the Washington Post reporter asked me a question in whatever,
What did you mean by that?
earlier this year, whenever it was, January or February.
she was asking me a hypothetical question, knowing all the information that I know now.
And so it's just out of context.
was asked a year and a half later.
I mean, it wasn't December 14th or whatever
And so I stand by the quote.
And so standing by the quote, does that

To the extent you can answer that, go ahead.
So when you say convening an alternate slate in 2022, I mean, they
the planning for what they did.
I mean, I wasn't a part of what they did.
I wasn't part of any of
Whether what they did was appropriate or not, I have
I guess I was just trying --
1 wasn't part of any of that.
I guess I was trying to understand a little bit more

I interpret that meaning going against the fact that the election had been certified

And so, again, she was asking me a hypothetical question a year and a
In fairness, I don't know when the timelines for the challenges were exhausted

what was appropriate and when it was appropriate, I don't know.
My point was, we have a process for having an election.
When those challenges fail, that needs to be respected.
Now, what they did on December 14th or whatever, whether that was in the

point was, I don't approve of anything that goes against the processes and the laws that

Well, thank you for that explanation.
the time that you gave the interview to the Washington Post reporter, right?
I mean, he called me as soon as the article came out.
And what did he tell you or what did he say?
Oh, I mean, I've known David a long time.
So tell us about that conversation.
don't remember exactly what we talked about.
It was a brief conversation and then we
There wasn't anything special about it.
Was he upset about the quotes in The Washington Post?
Did he want to provide you with any additional information or

I mean, we didn't really talk about it.
It was more of just a personal

I think so, very briefly, in the context of the article and, you know -- but it

Help me to understand a little bit more.
the conversation, what was the context?
Other than it coming up in
Was he conveying information to you or the

And then he asked me how I was doing and asked me how everything was

Did he tell you that -- did he make any comments about the meeting

So I don't -- we didn't get into a lot of details like that.
But -- so is it -- did he provide you with any explanation for the

Do you have anything further on that?

Mr. Isakson, just a couple of other kind of wrap-up questions here.
Did you ever learn how they were admitted?

We're still spinning all around the room here.
I don't know what that was.
admitted and met inside the capitol on December 14th?
Did you ever come to learn how a replacement for you was -- how

So my question was, did you ever come to learn how the electors were

I was sent a few pages by the Washington Post reporter.
that's what you're referring to, but that's how I knew I wasn't on the list.
what you're talking about, but I don't know if it was a certificate or not.

And I can pull it back up here really quickly.
Let me just pull it up real quick.

So this is -- it's titled memo here.
from David Shafer as chairman of the Georgia Republican Party and chairman of the

Have you seen this document before?
This may be what the Washington Post reporter sent me.
percent certain, but it looks like it.
And did you receive it from Mr. Shafer or any other source
Yeah, this is what -- yeah, this is what -- this is what she sent me.
I remember that list with the -- looking -- I remember the list looking like
So it has the list on the bottom, but at the top, the first kind of paragraph here
This is the certificate on page 2.
Let me zoom in a little bit here.
under the title "Certificate of the Votes of the 2020 Electors from Georgia" --
-- the first paragraph begins, "We, the undersigned, being the duly elected

What's your assessment of that use of that language, "the duly elected and
I didn't mean to interject, but --
-- I don't understand the context of that question.
Are you asking for his legal opinion?
